Title: Strong and weak convergence in $\ell^1$
Content:
Let $\ell^1$ be the space of absolutely summable real or complex sequences. Let us say that a sequence $(x_1, x_2, \ldots)$ of vectors in $\ell^1$ converges weakly to $x \in \ell^1$ if for every bounded linear functional $\varphi \in (\ell^1)^*$, $\varphi(x_n) \rightarrow \varphi(x)$ as $n \to \infty$. How may I show that weak convergence, in this sense, is the same as the usual convergence-in-norm? It's clear the weak convergence implies pointwise convergence, but that's not good enough to conclude strong convergence... By linearity, it suffices to prove that if $\varphi(x_n) \longrightarrow 0$ for every $\varphi \in (\ell^1)^*$, then $\| x_n \| \longrightarrow 0$. Let $x_n(k)$ be the $k$-th component of the vector $x_n$. Then, $x_n(k) \longrightarrow 0$ for every $k$, so $\sup_n |x_n(k)| < \infty$ for each $k$, and this implies
$$\lim_{N \to \infty} \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{k=1}^{N} |x_n(k)| = 0$$
This is almost what I want, but the limits are the wrong way around. The obvious next thing to try is to construct some clever functional, or even a family of clever functionals, but I can't think of anything useful here. I can see that pointwise convergence alone is not good enough — if $x_n$ is the standard basis vector, then $x_n \longrightarrow 0$ pointwise, but $\| x_n \| = 1$ for all $n$. The fact that it doesn't converge strongly can be detected by the linear functional $\varphi(x_n) = \sum_k x_n(k)$, but I'm at a loss as to how to generalise this.
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $\left\{y^{(k)}\right\}\subset \ell^1$ a sequence which converges weakly to $0$ in $\ell^1$ . We assume this sequence doesn't converge in norm, there exists $\varepsilon >0$ such that $\lVert y^{(k)}\rVert\geqslant 5\varepsilon$ (if it's not the case, we will take a subsequence). We will show that there exists $x\in \ell^{\infty}$ , $\|x\|_{\ell^\infty}\leqslant 1,$ and a subsequence $\left\{y^{(k_j)}\right\}$ such that $\langle x,y^{(k_j)}\rangle >\varepsilon$ . Let $k_0=0$ . Let $n_0$ such that $\sum_{n\geqslant n_0+1}|y^{(k_0)}_n|<\varepsilon$ . For $0\leqslant n\leqslant n_0$ , we choose $x_n = \operatorname{sgn}y^{(k_0)}_n$ . For all $x\in \ell^{\infty}$ , $\|x\|_{\ell^\infty}\leqslant 1$ whose $n_0$ first coordinates are $x_n$ we have $\langle x,y^{(k_0)}\rangle>\varepsilon$ .
The weak convergence implies that every entry of the sequence $\{y^{(k)}\}$ converges to zero (by testing against the elementary functions $e^{(k)}$ defined as $e^{(k)}_n=\delta_{n,k}$ , where $\delta$ is the Kronecker delta). From this, we can find $k_1>k_0$ such that for $k\geqslant k_1$ we have $\sum_{n=0}^{n_0} |y_n^{(k)}|<\varepsilon$ . As before, we can find $n_1>n_0$ such that $\sum_{n\geqslant n_1+1}|y_n^{(k_1)}|<\varepsilon$ and define $x_{n_0+1},\cdots,x_{n_1}$ as $x_n=\operatorname{sgn} y^{(k_1)}_n$ . It follows that, if $\|x\|_{\ell^\infty}\leqslant 1$ , with the $n_1$ -first coordinates defined as above, we have $$ \langle x,y^{(k_1)}\rangle = \sum_{n\leqslant n_0} x_n y ^{(k_1)}_n + \sum_{n_0+1\leqslant n\leqslant n_1} x_n y ^{(k_1)}_n  + \sum_{n\geqslant n_1+1} x_n y ^{(k_1)}_n \geqslant $$ $$ \geqslant  -\sum_{n\leqslant n_0} |y ^{(k_1)}_n| + \sum_{n_0+1\leqslant n\leqslant n_1} |y ^{(k_1)}_n|  - \sum_{n\geqslant n_1+1} |y ^{(k_1)}_n| =$$ $$ \geqslant  -2\sum_{n\leqslant n_0} |y ^{(k_1)}_n| + \|y^{(k_1)}\|_{\ell_1}  -2\sum_{n\geqslant n_1+1} |y ^{(k_1)}_n| > -2\varepsilon +5\varepsilon-2\varepsilon=\varepsilon. $$ Iterating, we will get a subsequence $\left\{ y^{(k_j)}\right\}$ and a $x\in \ell^{\infty}$ such that $\langle x,y^{(k_j)}\rangle>\varepsilon$ . This contradicts the weak convergence to $0$ .
